On 21 May 2021, an IED by Al Shabaab militants detonated, targeting a Kenya police officers convoy along Banisa-Takaba road near Darkale Township (Mandera East, Mandera). Three police officers were killed.

On 18 May 2021, a remote controlled IED by Al Shabaab militants detonated, targeting Kenya military forces (KDF) along the Kenya-Somali border near Baure town (Basuba, Lamu East). At least eight soldiers were killed in the explosion.

On 3 May 2021, an IED by a suspected Al Shabaab militants detonated, targeting construction workers at the Kenya-Somalia security border wall in the vicinity of Ishakani village, near Kiunga town (Lamu East, Lamu). Two people were killed and one other injured.

On 24 March 2021, an IED by suspected Al Shabaab militants detonated, targeting a bus travelling along the Lafey-Mandera town route in Koromi village (Bulla Mpya, Mandera East, Mandera). Three people were killed and several others injured.

On 23 March 2021, an IED by Al Shabaab militants detonated, targeting civilians ferrying water to the construction site of the Kenya-Somalia security border wall near Kiunga town (Lamu East, Lamu). One person was killed.

On 28 January 2021, an IED by Al Shabaab militants detonated, targeting a Kenya police officer convoy travelling along the Omarjillo-Arabia road near Arabia town ( Mandera East, Mandera). At least one police officer was killed and three others injured.
On 12 January 2021, suspected Al Shabaab militants bombed a telecommunications mast at Darkale center in Banissa town (Banissa, Mandera). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

On 11 January 2021, an IED by Al Shabaab militants detonated, targeting civilians traveling in a Toyota land cruiser along the Banisa-Takaba road near Takaba town (Mandera West, Mandera). The explosion partially damaged the vehicle transporting examination material to Mandera town. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

On 30 December 2020, an IED by Al Shabaab militants, targeting an ambulance with pregnant woman, detonated in the vicinity of El Wak town (Mandera South, Mandera). The explosion killed one person. The ambulance was on the way to El wak referral hospital when it came under attack.

On 17 December 2020, an IED by a suspected Al Shabaab returnee detonated targeting his 16 year old girlfriend in their rented house in Katito town (Gatanga, Muranga). The girl escaped unhurt. [women targeted: girls]

On 29 November 2020, an Al Shabaab IED, targeting a Kenya police forces convoy travelling between Jabibar and Rhamu road, detonated near Rhamu town (Mandera North, Mandera). Five police officers were injured.

On 8 September 2020, an Al Shabaab RCIED detonated targeting a Kenya security forces (KDF) and Somali Somali security forces (SNA) convoy travelling between Fino village and Sheikh Barrow village (Lafey, Mandera). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

Around 18 May 2020 (as reported), a heavy explosion hit a military vehicle carrying Kenyan police in an area between Harar and Fifty (Khorof Harar, Wajir East, Wajir). Seven police officers were injured.
On 16 May 2020, KDF troops launched airstrikes, targeting Al Shabaab militants in Wajir area (Wajir, Wajir East). Casualty figures are unknown (Coded as 0).
On 24 April 2020, two police officers died in a bomb attack in Dabacity near El Wak (Mandera South, Mandera). Al Shabaab claimed responsibility.
On 15 March 2020, two policemen were killed in an IED explosion by an unidentified group as they drove to the scene of another attack on an ambulance in Hulugho (Hulugho, Ijara, Garissa).
On 13 March 2020, two police officers were killed when their vehicle hit an IED in Garissa (Dujis, Garissa). It is suspected that the IED was planted by Al Shabaab militants.
Around 11 March 2020, police escaped unharmed when they were targeted with an explosive by Al Shabaab militants in Jabibar on the road between Bambo and Rhamu town (Mandera North, Mandera).

Around 20 February 2020 (as reported), an IED exploded targeting a bus carrying Christians along the Nairobi-Mandera road (Mandera East, Mandera), killing four and injuring several others. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility.
On 27 December 2019, 2 Kenyan security forces were killed and 7 others injured when their vehicle ran over an IED on the Kutulo-Khorof Kharar road in Wajir (Al Shabaab assumed responsible).
On 23 December 2019, an IED exploded near military forces patrolling in Lagh Kutulo, Wajir (Al Shabaab assumed responsible). No injuries were reported.

On 12 October 2019, 10 police officers from Harhar GSU Camp in Garissa County, on patrol along the Damajale Harehare road near the Kenya-Somalia border, died as their vehicle ran through an explosive device. Police forces later identified the group leader that planted the device as an Al Shabaab militant who joined the group in 2012.

actor2: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Border Patrol Unit
notes: 15 July: Two border patrol police were injured by an IED planted by Al Shabaab in Kiunga- Somalia road.
15 June: Several police officers feared dead after their vehicle ran over an IED planted by Al Shabaab in Wajir county. Fatalities coded as 3
On Jun 15th 2019, in Wajir, a police vehicle was hit by an IED. Officers were injured. No fatalities reported.
19 January: Two people were injured when suspected IED went off outside a restaurant in Nairobi.
29 December: Two children were killed by explosive devices while herding in Samburu. No group has claimed responsibility

actor2: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Border Patrol Unit
notes: 25 December: unknown gunmen threw a grenade at a Kenya border police patrol, leaving some injured in Mandera town.
On 8 December 2018, three civilians were injured when their lorry was hit by an IED near Sankuri (Lamu county). The device was suspected to have been planted by Al Shabaab.

On 16 October 2018, Al Shabaab militants alleged that they had destroyed two Kenyan military vehicles with an IED, killing and injuring an unspecified number of soldiers. The alleged incident took place between Fino and Arabiya villages in Mandera county (coordinates for Fino, Mandera, used). Subsequent reports indicate that the IED exploded before the military vehicles were in range, resulting in no casualties or fatalities.
On or before October 2nd, Al Shabaab forces shelled a Kenyan military base in Mirarani (Lamu county). Casualties mentioned (unknown death or injuries coded as zero fatalaties).
26 September 2018: An IED hit a Kenyan military vehicle in Daba-city village in Mandera County.

On 26 September 2018, two children were killed near Nakuyen village, North Pokot after they touched and played with a RDX explosive device, which exploded. The device had been left in the area by the military who had conducted an operation locally.

On 11 September 2018, a police vehicle belonging to the Anti-Stock Theft Unit was hit by an explosion in Kotulo ward (Wajir). They began searching for suspects afterwards. There were no reports of police injuries or deaths.

On 29 August 2018, five Kenyan soldiers were killed and ten wounded when their vehicle hit a landmine on the road between Kiunga and Sankuri (Lamu, coordinates for Kiunga used). It was not clear who had planted the device, though a pro-Al Shabaab radio station in Somalia subsequently claimed that Al Shabaab had killed at least 20 Kenyan soldiers in an (unverified) attack in the area of Lamu, which was reported to be an ambush. Until further information comes to light, this has been coded as a single event of remote violence by an unknown group, killing five.
On 13 August 2018, three border wall workers were killed after their vehicle ran over an Improvised Explosive Device. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility. Another source reported tens of fatalities.
On 8 August 2018, five Kenyan soldiers were killed and six others wounded when their vehicle was blown up by an IED near the town of Bodhei. Al-Shabaab claimed the attack.

On 16 July 2018, an IED intended to target Kenya soldiers exploded after their vehicle had passed the device, on the road between Tarbaj and Kutulo (Tarbaj coded as the location, with coordinates of the site of the attack accurate to 3km taken from the source). There were no casualties, and the source attributes the attack to Al Shabaab.
05 July. Several police officers were injured after their vehicle ran over a homemade bomb between Handaro and Sangailu on the Lamu-Garissa border. Al Shabaab suspected.

On 2 July 2018, a Kenyan military vehicle was hit by an IED (the source attributes the attack to Al Shabaab) on the road between Mandera and Lafey, 5km from Lafey. Fatalaties are unclear (coded at low estimate of 3). An additional IED was safely dismantled by Kenyan army reinforcements in the area later that same day.

actor2: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) General Service Unit
notes: 17 June. An al Shabaab IED detonated in Tarbaj, killing 8 GSU police officers. Al Shabaab claims 15 fatalities. Following the attack al Shabaab took the officer's weapons and fled.

06 June. Five Kenyan paramilitary police were killed when their vehicle struck a homemade landmine in Liboi. Al Shabaab suspected as perpetrators. Al Shabaab claims they have killed 25 Kenyan soldiers. The attack began with an IED blast, which killed 22. Three others were shot by the attackers.
08 May. A suspected al Shabaab IED targets a military convoy in Daba Siti. One soldier dead.
14 March. A roadside IED results in two KDF soldiers killed and an unspecified number and an unspecific number wounded. Perpetrating actor not named by the source.
Al Shabaab fire several mortar rounds towards KDF base in El Ram, Mandera County. No casualties, assailants escaped.
Al Shabaab launched mortar file against a military base in El Wak over two days. Casualties reported, number not provided.
Al Shabaab launched mortar file against a military base in El Wak over two days. Casualties reported, number not provided.
IED targets Kenya Police land cruiser headed to location of previous al Shabaab attack near Kutulo. No casualties & no damages.

A Kenyan official says four children have been killed by an explosive device that went off in a field where they grazing livestock. Mandera Governor Ali Roba is blaming devices that Britain might have planted during its colonial occupation of Kenya for the deaths on Saturday. He asked security agents to clear the fields of any devices from before Kenya gained independence in 1963.
Suspected al-Shabab militants have destroyed a Safaricom communication mast in Kutulo, Wajir County.

Schoolchildren were playing with a device when it exploded. At least five children have been killed in an explosion in Banisa, Mandera County. Banisa Sub-County Deputy County Commissioner Mathias Chisambo said the schoolchildren were playing with a grenade they had found in a grazing field.

'A truck contracted by a UN agency partner in Garissa county ran over an IED planted in the road. All three contracted employees sustained major injuries as a result of the attack. Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, the area is prone to extremist activities by Al-Shabaab. The workers were delivering food commodities at the time.'

At least one police officer was killed and two others injured when the vehicle in which they were travelling ran over an improvised explosive device (IED) in the coastal Lamu County on Sunday evening.
3 people were injured when a grenade exploded in Eskot market, in Garbatulla. The man carrying the grenade, a 32-year old chemist, was killed whilst holding it.

At least two KDF soldiers were killed on 28 August when their Armoured Personnel Carrier (APC) triggered off a roadside bomb explosion in Damasa Lafey Sub-County, Mandera [northeast of the country]. Three others were injured.
The Kenya Defence Forces [KDF] on Sunday [20 August] resumed bombing Boni Forest which Al Shabaab has used as a base to launch attacks.

Five police officers have been killed by an Al-Shabaab IED while on patrol along Bothai-Ijara road, within Garissa County. One officer sustained injuries during the attack while another one managed to escape unhurt.
Two people were injured after the vehicle they were travelling in ran over a landmine at Nyongoro along the Garsen-Lamu road.

A powerful explosion caused by a land mine, occurred in parts of NFD [Northern Frontier District, Kenya'snortheastern region], targeting Kenyan military forces and resulting in casualties in an area called Abdi Ali in Liboi town.
The police have launched air strikes in Boni Forest to attack Al Shabaab fighters

Eight people including four school children and four police officers were killed in a roadside bomb attack planted by suspected Al Shabaab fighters that occurred in Kiunga, Lamu on Tuesday. The police officers were escorting the school children to Kiunga from Mararani, when the lorry was hit by an IED. Following the blast, al Shabaab opened fire on the victims.
An Improvised Device (IED) exploded when a vehicle ran over it. The vehicle was heading to Mandera from Elwak. No one was injured in the attack.
Nine Kenyan soldiers were killed, and ten others were injured when a road side bomb explosed. Al Shabaab confirmed claimed responsibility of the attack.
Four cilivilians killed and 11 injured when a passenger bus struck a roadside bomb suspected to have been planted by Al Shabaab between Lafey and Elwak in Madera county.
A KDF convoy was transporting military supplies to Somalia when it was targeted in a massive roadside explosion, just outside of Liboi town. Several soldiers wounded.

At least three people were killed after a car they were travelling in hit a landmine along Dadaab-Kulan road in Garissa County [eastern Kenya]. Al Shabaab believed responsible. One person escaped with injuries. The Star reports four dead.
On Monday, a team of security officers escaped an IED explosion unhurt as they hunted down a group of al-Shabab militants who had planted landmines in Gerille area, Wajir County.
An explosive device aimed at a military lorry went off between Kiunga and Ishakani. It exploded early and there were no casualties.

Two soldiers from Kenya Defence forces were killed, and another wounded in an IED explosion. Al-Shabaab claimed responibility of the attack. Another IED exploded in the same area on the same day before a Kenyan vehicle passed, leaving the passengers unharmed.
Seven police officers and a civilian were killed when an armoured vehicle drove over a roadside bomb in southeastern Kenya. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility

At last five police officers were killed and one other injured after an Improvised Explosive Devise tore their vehicle along the Malelei-Kulan Road in Liboi, Garissa County. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility of the attacks
At least three policemen were killed in an IED explosions in Liboi, Garissa County, near the Kenya - Somalia border. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility of the attacks.

At least five policemen were killed in an IED explosions in Mandera, near the Kenya - Somalia border. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility of the attacks. Police later arrested several Al-Shabaab suspects behind the attacks in Mandera county. One of the susptect is a high ranking Al-Shabaab explosives expert
On 24 May 2017, two police officers were killed in an explosion between Malelei and Kulan in Garissa, near Hagadera refugee camp

A Kenyan official was killed on Wednesday after a vehicle he was traveling in ran over an improvised explosive device in Elwak area near Kenya-Somalia border. Mandera East divisional police commander Timothy Muasya said the explosive device was buried on the ground by unknown people. The driver survived with serious injuries after the 1 p.m. incident. Police have blamed the attacks on Al-Shabaab militants who are operating in the area.
At least four people died on Tuesday when their vehicle set off an improvised explosive device in a small Kenyan town near the border with Somalia, police said.Al-Shabaab militants were suspected

Further reports have emerged of the damage caused by an explosion that targeted a Kenyan army convoy in Garissa County, northeastern Kenya. The explosion which was a land mine attack was targeted on a Kenya army convoy in between Liboi town and Kulan village in Garissa county. Kenyan police said the explosion injured several soldiers with three sustaining serious injuries. The injured were airlifted to a hospital in the capital, Nairobi, for treatment. No one who has claimed responsibility for the attack given that al-Shabab has severally taken credit for attacks that have happened in northeastern Kenya.

At least six Kenyan security officers were injured in a bomb blast on Monday in the northeast region of Garissa near the Somali border. Somali militant group Al-Shabaab has claimed responsibility for the attack, saying its fighters killed four government soldiers, including two commanders.

At least two children were killed and three others injured on 25/03 after explosion went off in a unnamed village in Mandera county. Authorities suspect al Shabaab, though no group has claimed responsibility.

Three people are injured in Mandera after their fuel tanker ran over an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) between Kotulo and Chuma Mrefu. Al Shabaab suspected. A similar attack against police occurred earlier in the week.
Suspected al Shabaab target police with an IED in Mandera. No causalities.

Al Shabaab gunmen detonated explosives at Boshari Guesthouse during the early morning hours. Twelve killed, others injured. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility, saying the targets of their attacks were Christians. Police later imposed a dusk till dawn curfew.

Al Shabaab claimed responsibility for double roadside explosions targeted Kenyan defence forces near the town of Mandera on 09/09. Pro-al shabaab media outlets, citing unnamed commander reported that at least 4 Kenyan army soldiers died in the IED blasts on the KDF military convoy.

A Muslim cleric died on Saturday evening after his vehicle hit an improvised explosive device (IED) in the Kenyan coastal county of Lamu, near the border with Somalia. Al Shabaab are the suspected perpetrators.
Suspected al Shabaab detonate an explosive at a police building injuring one officer.
A KDF convoy runs over a al Shabaab-planted landmine in Ishakani, five injured.
Al Shabaab are reported to have struck Damasa border town and destroyed a Safaricom communication mast and a water pump using explosives. No reported human causality or violence.
One dead and three injured when an ambulance hit a suspected al-Shabaab planted land mine in Hulugho.

An IED detonated at Mandera, near the Somali border on 11/06. No causalities reported. The Mandera County Commissioner said the incident, which took place at Border Point Three area near custom offices, had targeted security officers manning the border area and was likely caused by al Shabaab.

A convoy transporting Kenyan defence forces (KDF) was targeted in a roadside bomb explosion outside Liboi town near Somali border by suspected al Shabaab. The bomb blast has destroyed one of vehicles in the convoy, causing unidentified casualties as Kenyan military did not comment on the IED attack.
Six police (or seven - Shabelle Media Network) officers are killed when their vehicle struck an IED in Lamu, suspected al Shabaab responsible.

Three people were killed and two others injured after an explosion went off in a vehicle within Mandera town on 28/12. Al Shabaab suspected. The explosion caused a group of locals to hold a demonstration against military forces, mistakenly believing members of the military had been responsible for the deaths of the civilians.

A member of al Shabaab, attempting to plant a roadside bomb, dies when the device exploded prematurely. The perpetrator was believed to be hurried when he saw that the police had noticed his activities and attempted top stop him. A matter of dispute, the Daily Nation reported police had killed the perpetrator, followed by the explosion.

A roadside bomb or landmine, suspected to have origin with al Shabaab, detonates in Mandara, targeting and killing a group of five (later determined to be seven) police officers. The landmine was planted inside the customs and border compound. The attack come a day after an ambush on a group of soldiers in the town.
A soldier was killed and six others injured in the border town of Hulugho after an Al Shabaab IED detonated. Al Shabaab, in taking credit, claims eight dead.
An al Shabaab-planted explosive attached to a military vehicle causes seven soldier deaths.
Al Shabaab targets police with an IED in Lamu on 13/07. Three deaths reported.

Al Shabaab attacks Mandera town, throwing grenades into homes while people slept on 07/07. 14 dead. Al Shabaab later officially claimed responsibility, declaring they were specifically targeting Christians.
Three KDF members are injured in an al Shabaab IED attack Milimani on 21/06.
Four are killed and their bodies burnt in a grenade attack on a Wajir shop. Perpetrators not known.
An IED explodes in Mandera following a similar attack across the Somali border in Beled Hawo. No reported causalities.
Unknown assailants on the evening of 13/02 hurled two hand grenades at police officers on patrol in Wajir town. No reported injuries.

Three people were critically injured after a hand grenade was hurled at a food kiosk in Mandera town. The reason for the attack is not known. The perpetrators escaped. Authorities suspect one of the victims may have been linked to al Shabaab.

Unknown people hurled a grenade on the evening of 21/12 at a residential area in Mandera. The explosive was targeted at a group of people who were chewing miraa at Green View near the National Cereals and Produce Board depot around 7pm. No one was injured.

An unknown assailant threw two grenades into a cafe in Garissa on Wednesday night, wounding two people. The source references several attacks from al Shabaab in the area, but does not speculate as to who is responsible for the Wednesday blast.
At least one patron is killed when suspected al Shabaab attack a country club bar in Wajir. Witnesses claim two blasts followed by gunfire.

A pro-al Shabaab website published a report that al Shabaab has claimed the responsibility of the killing of 36-non local Kenyans at a quarry in Koromei area near Mandera in the night of 01/12. The statement claimed that the attack on Koromei was part of series of attacks executed by the Mujahidin to serve as a response to Kenyas occupation of Somalia, the airstrikes by Kenyan warplanes and the killing of innocent Somalis.
At least five people were wounded on Sunday evening after unknown men hurled a hand grenade at pedestrians in Garissa town, northern Kenya.
Twelve people were injured, four of them critically at Bula Sheikh in Garissa town when unknown assailants hurled a grenade at a shop.

A senior Kenyan county official escaped death narrowly after an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) exploded as he was being driven to his office in the border town of Rhamu, Mandera. Perpetrators not known. Two injuries reported.

Six people have been injured in a grenade attack in Kenyas north-eastern district of Garissa. The report said a grenade was thrown by unnamed attackers on Ngamia Road near the district hospital. Though the attackers have not been identified, the source references a history of al Shabaab attacks in the area.
At least eight are killed in twin grenade attacks in Wajir. Assailants not known.
Suspected al Shabaab attack a police post with grenades, but did not cause bodily harm or property damage.
Six are reported injured following a explosion near a hospital in Mandera. Perpatrators unknown, though the attack may be related to a nearby ethnic clash between Garre and Degodia clans.

Gunmen hurled explosives at the Mandera county government headquarters causing damages. The buildings wing that houses finance and other executive offices was destroyed in the attack. Perpetrators believed to be al Shabaab. No injuries reported.
In response to recent attacks in the Lamu area, Kenya air forces launch attacks on Lamu Forest, believed to be where the suspected assailants are hiding. Causalities not known.

At least one person was killed and several injured late in the day in the grenade blast in a restaurant in Kenyas north-eastern town of Wajir, before spraying the building with bullets and escaping. No one claimed immediate responsibility for the killing.
An unidentified attacker hurled a hand grenade along Ngamia Road area in Garissa injuring seven civilians.

actor1: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1991-2018) Liyu Police
notes: A suspected member of the Liyu Police shoots and kills a ONLF sympathising shopkeeper, throws a dud grenade into a crowd, flees, is tackled by a group of villagers and is arrested by police.

A grenade attack at a garage in the eastern Kenyan town of Garissa left one killed and three people wounded. The motive for the attack, which took place close to the Somali border, was not immediately clear.

Twelve people from the Degodia clan were during the nighttime hours killed when militia from the Garre clan raided Gunane village in Tarbaj constituency. Seven others are admitted to the Wajir District Hospital with serious injuries. Wajir county commissioner Naftali Mungathia said the militia stormed the village at around 11pm and hurled a rocket propelled grenade at the villagers who were asleep. Conflicting reports hold 18 deaths.

A policeman and a civilian were injured in the coastal city of Mombasa, Kenya in a grenade attack during the evening hours. Regional police commander said the incident took place after the police had arrested a [al Shabaab] suspect before he was rescued by his two accomplices who hurled a grenade at the officers.
Suspected al-Shabaab militants hurled grenades in co-ordinated attacks against civilians in Garissa town Tuesday evening (May 20th), injuring ten people.

Nairobi: Ten people were killed and over 70 wounded in two bomb attacks at a busy market in Nairobi. According to authorities, first blast in the capital occurred next to a 14-seater matatu, or public minibus, and the second was inside a shop in Gikomba Market close to Nairobis central business district. Al Shabaab are suspected as perpetrators. Preceding the attack the British government had issued a travel advisory due to threats. Police forces launch a manhunt operation for the perpetrators the following day.

Nairobi: Ten people were killed and over 70 wounded in two bomb attacks at a busy market in Nairobi. According to authorities, first blast in the capital occurred next to a 14-seater matatu, or public minibus, and the second was inside a shop in Gikomba Market close to Nairobis central business district. Al Shabaab are suspected as perpetrators. Preceding the attack the British government had issued a travel advisory due to threats. Police forces launch a manhunt operation for the perpetrators the following day.

At least three people were killed and 60 wounded when bombs exploded in two buses on a busy highway in the Kenyan capital Nairobi. Both explosions took place around 5.45pm. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attacks -- although Kenyan authorities are currently engaged in a major security crackdown on suspected supporters of neighbouring Somalias Al-Qaeda-linked Shebab rebels. This comes a day after a similar attack in Mombasa. Several suspected were arrested in connection with the blasts within the week.

Four people were killed and several others injured in twin attacks in Mombasa. One blast occurred at a well-known beach hotel, the Reef Hotel, in the Nyari area of the city, and the other in the Mwembe Tayari area, near the city centre. Al Shabaab is suspected.

At least 4 people were last night killed in a car explosion outside Pangani police station. Police say the blast killed 2 officers and 2 suspects they had arrested earlier. The motive for the blast is not known, though the incident came in the midst of a countrywide security crackdown against illegal immigrants and terror suspects. It was later learned the suspects had explosives strapped to themselves and were suicide bombers.

Two loud explosions were heard during the night-time hours at Dadaab Refugee Camp airstrip. It is believed that an al Shabaab affiliated camp militia was targeting security forces near the airstrip with grenades. The third grenade was thrown, but it failed to detonate. No reported injury or death.

Three simultaneous blasts occur in the Somali populated Eastleigh district. At least six are dead and scores injured. Al Shabaab are suspected. In the days following the explosion police arrest over 650 possible suspects.
Suspected al Shabaab fighters hurl hand grenades at a border post, but caused no injury. It is believed the ordinance may have partially malfunctioned.
A bomb was in the early morning hurled at a primary school in Likoni, Mombasa. Police say the device exploded inside the school compound, but no injuries have been reported.

A blast of unknown origin occurs at Jomo Kenyatta International Airport during the evening hours. The body of a Somali national was later discovered, however his causes of death is believed to be from gunfire. Nevertheless, authorities believe his death is related to the blast perpetrators. The following three days several arrests were made.

Three IEDs were detonated in the vicinity of firewood distribution centre in IFO 1 (Dadaab District) in the morning of 08/12. Reports indicate that the first explosion targeted the rear police escort vehicle of the regular morning convoy to IFO 1 and Dagahaley. The second set targeted the police responders, of whom a number had by then arrived at the scene. No one was injured by any of the blasts. The police vehicle initially targeted by the perpetrators only sustained slight damages. There were gunshots fired by the police after the second explosion. One man was injured in its aftermath, trampled by a panicked crowd running from the scene.
A hand grenade is thrown at a police vehicle in Ukunda. The five officers present escaped unhurt.
One person is injured after suspected al Shabaab detonated an explosive in the Somali-populated Eastleigh district of Nairobi.

At least ten are injured in a grenade attack at a nightclub in Diani, 25km outside of Mombasa. The attack occurred around 4am. Witnesses claim they saw an individual lob the explosive into a group of people, though the persons identity remain unknown. The target of the blast may have been a group of British tourists present in the bar.

An explosive device believed to be an IED targeted a police vehicle in the vicinity of Juba Primary School in Dagahley Camp in Dadaab District in the morning of 30/12. The police vehicle was escorting an NGO vehicle carrying out borehole refuelling. One police officer was reportedly injured by the explosion. The vehicle was severely damaged.

Suspected al Shabaab attackers detonate an explosive on a public bus, killing four and injuring 30 in the Pangani-Eastleigh section of the city. Eastleigh is known for its large population of ethnic Somalis, and may have been the specific target of the attackers. In the following days the death toll from the blast rose to six.

Two people were killed and at least three others injured in two explosions targeting police officers in the north-eastern Kenyan town of Wajir. The explosions took place near the Baraza park in the town. The injured were taken to Wajir general hospital. Reports say there have been several arrests in connection with the explosions.
An unidentified person threw a hand grenade into a group of British tourists in the Likoni area of Mombasa. The grenade failed to explode.
A young boy is killed and three others injured after a landmine detonated in Mandera border town. The group many have been playing with the mine, not aware that it was dangerous.

Al Shabaab militants shoot and kill two civilians at Mandera, a Kenya/Somali border town. On Thursday night, two police officers were seriously injured after a hand grenade was hurled into their vehicle.
A device suspected to be an IED exploded in front of the Central AP camp in Mandera in the evening of 05/09. No casualties were reported.
Grenade attack by Garre militia leaves 16 dead
Al Shabaab-linked suspects throw grenade, injuring several civilians
Attackers suspected to be linked to Al Shabaab throw grenade into church compound, injuring civilians
Roadside bomb placed by unknown group kills police officer
Two injured in grenade attack at vote-tallying centre
Bomb in Eastleigh injures one; Somali man arrested and charged in the attack
Two grenades thrown at elections tallying centre in Mandera; initial reports of one injured
Grenade attack kills public works officer and injures member of Kenya Red Cross
Grenade attack on KDF soldier; suspects unknown
IED explodes in Dadaab refugee camp, injuring three police officers

assoc_actor_2: WFP: World Food Programme; Aid Workers (Kenya)
notes: Unknown attackers hurl two grenades into World Food Programmes compound; no injuries reported. The attackers fled into Somalia, leading investigators to conclude that they were Somali in origin
Grenade attack by unknown group kills two civilians. Officials noted that the attackers were targeting non-Somalis within the camp. Somali refugees were also among the victims
Woman injured in grenade attack by suspected Al Shabaab
Grenade attack outside mosque by unknown group; police blame Al Shabaab
Grenade attack by unknown group in Eastleigh; several injured. Police later arrested 8 Yemeni nationals and one Somali in connection with the attack
Explosive device planted near voter registration centre injures one
Grenade attack at mosque kills five; Al Shabaab involvement suspected
Grenade attack blamed on Al Shabaab injures civilians and kills one
Police officer injured when unknown group throws grenade at police station
Police said to be targetting Somali residents of Eastleigh after grenade attack on bus
Police said to be targetting Somali residents of Eastleigh after grenade attack on bus; one person claims the police shot her cousin, a civilian
Al Shabaab detonates grenade in bus filled with civilians; ten killed
Grenade attack blamed on Al Shabaab injures three
Grenade attack at supermarket wounds one; perpetrators unknown
Explosion blamed on Al Shabaab injures civilians in Nairobi
Grenade attack on church blamed on Al Shabaab
Explosion blamed on Al Shabaab injures civilians in Nairobi
Twin blasts in Eastleigh target civilians
Al Shabaab throws grenade at police post in Kenya; no casualties
Grenade attack on church blamed on Al Shabaab
IED attack blamed on al Shabaab; police and civilians injured
Explosion injures police officers; officials suspect al Shabaab
Police beat villagers after IED explodes near police vehicle
Several injured in grenade attack in unrest following Muslim clerics killing
Grenade attack kills police officer in unrest following Muslim clerics killing

Local media reported an Al Shabaab operative gives explosive device disquised as a radio to civilian to hold, then remotely detonates the device. The man holding the device was killed instantly. Reuters stated that the man killed was a suicide bomber who detonated his device early by mistake. Many bystanders were wounded.
Al Shabaab operative gives explosive device disquised as gas cylinder to man to ferry, then remotely detonates the device. The man ferrying the gas cylinder was hospitalized with injuries
Vehicle in refugee camp hits explosive device; six wounded
Grenade attack on restaurant in Wajir region wounds five

assoc_actor_2: Aid Workers (Kenya); Police Forces of Kenya (2013-)
notes: 'One INGO incentive worker guard was injured when a Police vehicle escorting the INGO team was targeted by an IED.'
Grenade attack by suspected Al Shabaab militant leaves three dead and many injured at pub outside Mombasa
Police officers patrolling Kenya-Somalia border hit by remote-controlled explosive device they suspect was planted by Al Shabaab
IED explodes in Dadaab refugee camp. Human rights leader thought to be the target
One person was killed and three wounded in a blast outside a restaurant in the northeastern Kenyan town of Wajir
IED detonated in downtown Nairobi on Moi Avenue injuring 38 people. Al Shabaab or AS sympathizer suspected. One person later died in hospital.
Four people inured in a grenade attack at a primary school in the Ifo refugee camp in Garissa.
One person injured in grenade attack at a hotel in Wajir.
At least three people were wounded in a suspected grenade attack at a hotel in a refugee camp in northeastern Kenya
Four Kenyan soldiers were wounded Monday when a landmine exploded beneath their vehicle in the northeastern Mandera region
Suspected RCIED detonated killing one police officer as they were accompanying NGO workers.
Unidentified gunmen opened fire and threw two grenades into a night club after they tried to force entry. One woman was killed.
Man with suspected ties to Al-Shabab lobs grenade into church, kills 2
Grenade attack on Christian meeting leaves many casualties. Exact number not known.
Grenade attack leaves many casualties
Grenade attack blamed on Islamic militants
Somali youth set landmine at Kenyan army base; several soldiers injured
Four police officers escape death when their vehicle drives over a buried explosive.
Two Kenyan government officials escaped death narrowly after the car in which they were patrolling in missed a remote controlled explosive device in the eastern town of Mandera bordering Somalia.
Looting: On 29 March 2022, unidentified communal militia looted Kiambogo area in Tigania east (Tigania West, Meru), and made away with unknown number of animals. There were no fatalities.
Defusal: On 28 March 2022, police successfully defused an IED, allegedly placed by suspected Al Shabaab militants (targeting government vehicles) in Gherille, near El Wak (Mandera south, Mandera).

Security measures: On 23 March 2022, the government of Kenya declared a 30-day dusk-to-dawn curfew in several locations in Garissa region [coded to Garissa, Waberi, Garissa). This is following a recent spate of insecurity in the area, orchestrated by suspected clan militias.
Displacement: On 13 March 2022, about 1,000 residents of Bartabwa (Baringo North, Baringo), were displaced into the bush, following attacks from suspected Pokot militia.

Property destruction: On 12 March 2022, an unidentified militia raided several homes of livestock farmers, in Kanyabala village near Homa Bay (Homa Bay Central, Homa Bay), killing five cows and inflicting injuries to more than 10 by stabbing them. It is unclear whether this was an act of vigilante justice.

Property destruction: On 8 March 2022, unidentified armed group set alight a kitchen and a livestock shed of a woman who is also a dairy farmer in Kisamu village in the Lugari district (location coded to Lugari, Lugari, Kakamega). Two cows were burnt to death, while three others suffered serious burns. No further details.

Property destruction: On 4 March 2022, suspected Pokot militia vandalized equipment and raided animals in the Chesongoch livestock breeding centre in Chesongoch (Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet). 68 pedigree gala goats were raided, though some were recovered later.

assoc_actor_2: ODM: Orange Democratic Movement; Azimio La Umoja Coalition
notes: Property destruction: On 25 February 2022, an unidentified armed group vandalized campaign billboards affiliated to an ODM, Azimio la umoja gubernatorial candidate for Kakamega in Mumias town (Mumias West, Kakamega), due to suspected political rivalry.

Defusal: On 17 February 2022, a police bomb defusal squad successfully defused an IED, allegedly placed by suspected Al Shabaab militants (targeting security personnel) in Sankuri (Lamu East, Lamu County).
Displacement: Around 9 February 2022 (as reported), about 2,000 residents of Kaakong village (Kibish, Turkana county), were displaced following attacks from suspected Pokot militia.
Looting: Around 9 February 2022 (week of), suspected Tugen militia ambushed a lorry belonging to traders at Loruk (Tiaty, Baringo county) and stole an unknown number of goats.
Looting: On 31 January 2022, suspected Pokot pastoralists (allegedly from a neighboring county) raided the Lokusero Secondary School (Laikipia North, Laikipia County) and stole 23 sheep.

Looting: On 24 January 2022, suspected Pokot ethnic militias (pastoralists) attacked Rubere village near Kinamba (Githiga, Laikipia West, Laikipia). Three houses were burnt, and 50 cattle stolen during the incident.
Property destruction: On 23 January 2022, Al Shabaab militants fired and detonated explosives at a parking lot of a Chinese Construction Company in Bodhei (Lamu West, Lamu county), burning 8 trucks.

Property destruction: On 11 January 2022, armed 'bandits' (suspected to be Al Shabaab militants as described by some residents) set alight two houses in two villages, Mashogoni and Githurai), near Mpeketoni (Lamu West, Lamu county), where they slaughtered 2 goats, cooked and ate, before escaping into the forest after realizing the police were pursuing them.

Property destruction: On 7 January 2022, Al Shabaab militants attacked and destroyed a government security installation (communication mast) in Omar Jilo (Mandera East, Mandera), disabling communication services in the area. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility.

Security measures: On 5 January 2022, the government of Kenya declared a 30 day dusk-to-dawn curfew in several locations in lamu region [coded to Lamu, Mkomami, Lamu West). This is following a recent spate of killings in the area, allegedly orchestrated by Al Shabab militants.

Looting: On 5 January 2022, suspected Pokot pastoralists (allegedly from a neighboring county) raided a school near Mukogodo (Laikipia North, Laikipia County) and stole 9 animals. Security personnel helped recover seven of the animals at Mukogodo forest.
Detonation: On 11 December 2021, three Al Shabaab militants were killed after a bomb they were setting up went off accidentally in Damasa ( Lafey, Lafey, Mandera county).

Detonation: On 26 September 2021, a vehicle belonging to Al Shabaab militant ran over an IED belonging to the group between Sarira and Ras Kiamboni near Ishakani town (Lamu East, Lamu). At least fifteen militants were killed.

Security measures: Around 20 September 2021 (as reported), a multi-agency security team [coded as Police officers], started digging a tunnel from Kamwenje to Wangwachi (Laikipia West, Laikipia), to deter community militia.
Property destruction: On 9 September 2021, pokot militia burnt eight houses in Dam Samaki Village (Laikipia North, Laikipia).

Property destruction: On 5 September 2021, pokot militia burnt 40 houses in an area near Ol-moran town (Laikipia West, Laikipia). Hundreds of residents fled the area. Two members of the militia were arrested by security forces.

Displacement: On 4 July 2021, 300 families were displaced following retaliatory attacks along the borders of West Pokot, Elgeyo Marakwet and Baringo counties in Keiyo Valley village (Tambach, Keiyo North, Elgeyo Marakwet).
Property destruction: On 12 May 2021, Al Shabaab militants destroyed a Safricom mast in Sango village near Wargadud town (Lafey, Mandera).
Property destruction: On 12 May 2021, Al Shabaab militants destroyed a Safricom mast in Kheira Ali village, Lafey constituency (Lafey, Mandera).
Looting: On 4 April 2021, unidentified gunmen raided over 200 cattle in Arabal village in Kisanana district (Mogotio, Baringo).
Property destruction: On 19 January 2021, suspected Al Shabaab militants destroyed a communications mast in Sarman village near Mandera town (Mandera East, Mandera).
Property destruction: On 18 December 2020, suspected Al Shabaab militants destroyed a Safaricom mast in Elele village (Mandera South, Mandera). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

Arrests: On 2 December 2020, Kenya police arrested at least 200 suspected Mombasa Republican Council (MRC) members in Mombasa town (Mvita, Mombasa). The separatist group has been advocating for the coastal region to secede from the rest of Kenya.

On 9 October 2020, more than 200 armed men, suspected to be part of the Toposa ethnic group, set up camp in Mogilla village (Turkana West, Turkana). It is suspected that the group is attempting to occupy the only reliable water pan in the area.
Detonation: On 12 September 2020, three Al Shabaab militants were killed after an IED they were assembling exploded near Fafi town (Fafi, Garissa).

Property destruction: On 31 July 2020, several houses were set alight and 107 cows impounded by police during a police raid in Doldol village in Samburu East (location coded to Kiamumbi, Samburu Central, Samburu). More than 400 residents fled the village. According to some reports, some children are missing. No fatalities and/or casualties.
Property destruction: On 22 July 2020, suspected Al Shabaab members burned settlements in the area surrounding Yumbis (Fafi, Garissa) following an earlier armed clash with police in Yumbis.

Detonation: On 13 July 2020, a man, suspected to be a member of the Al Shabaab, was killed by a bomb he was planting on the roadside in Geneva near Mandera (Mandera East, Mandera). It is believed the bomb targeted security agents who frequently use the route.
Property destruction: On 24 June 2020, suspected Al Shabaab members looted shops and set them alight in Ijara (Garissa). No fatalities reported.

Property destruction: On 31 May 2020, police shot dead 23 donkeys, set alight 20 houses and vandalized and looted shops in Riongo Village near Tiati (Tiaty, Baringo) during a disarmament exercise. No fatalities/injuries reported.
Security measures: On 27 March 2020, the government implemented a national coronavirus curfew across Kenya (Starehe, Nairobi).
Property destruction: On 24 February 2020, at least 50 youths destroyed property on a private farm in Mai Mahiu (Naivasha, Nakuru) related to a land dispute.
Property destruction: On 19 February 2020, unidentified assailants destroyed a church in Mbale Town (Wundanyi/Mbale, Taita Taveta) related to a land dispute.
On 21 January 2020, police arrested 43 people in Eastleigh neighbourhood (Kamukunji, Nairobi) and detained them for two days on suspicion of several offenses related to 'terrorism'.
Property destruction: On 3 January 2020, assailants destroyed houses in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu) related to a land dispute.
On 22 December 2019, Al Shabaab militants stormed a construction site in Hagarsu (Mandera) and destroyed eqippment that was being used to construct the Arabia-Mandera road.

On 6 November 2019, the governments of Kenya and Uganda signed a Memorandum of Understanding on the disputed Mingingo Islands, in which the population of both nations are able to fish in the area. The MoU does not resolve the issue of ownership. The islands have been at the centre of a number of violent incidents, usually instigated by Ugandan security forces.

On Oct 19th 2019, around 30 Kariokor residents were evicted by county askaris over a claim that the illegal settlement had been built on the land of commonwealth war cemetry. Houses, built of iron sheets and timber, were demolished by bulldozers.

On Sept 2nd, after a first eviction phase which took place in July 2018, Kenyan Government started a second phase of evictions, tageting at least 60 families. Exact coordinates not reported, location coded as Narok with GP2.

Around Sept 1st 2019 (date not reported) Al Shabaab militants attached Yumbis, at the border with Somalia. The militants burnt the station and a vehicle ferrying medicine. No casualties were reported.
On Aug 14th, at least 250 families were evicted from Eldoret. The police used teargas to force out tenants who refused to move out of their houses.
On Aug 4th 2019, police officers dismantelled an Al Shabaab camp in Wakabheley, 25km inside Boni forest, in Lamu County (coded as Kiunga with GP2 for unfound Wakabheley). No fatalities reported.

On Jun 8th, in a security operation, police officers allegedly invaded Kanuni Ward and torched nine house, goats and valuable property. Police dismissed claims saying only one makeshift was torched during operation to flash out criminals.

On 14 November 2018, the embattled governor of Migori - Okoth Obado - was once again arrested, following raids on his properties in Migori and Nairobi. Heavily armed officers entered the properties as part of an invesigation into alleged extensive corruption, and officers recovered eight firearms in the governor's houses. The governor is under investigation for the murder of his girlfriend in September.
October 19th (on or before) police arrested 200 local residents described as 'suspects' after an earlier clash with gang members in Kayole.

On 16 October 2018, police arrested 40 people (including a local politician) over the invasion of a 900-acre Agricultural Development Corporation (ADC) land in Kisiwani, Kilifi County. The arrests took place in Kwa Ndomo in Sabaki ward.
On 8 October 2018, a truce was signed between the Pokot and Marakwet to put an end to raiding and reprisal attacks.
On 20 September 2018, an unspecified group burned 20 shops and an unknown number of houses in Nessuit village (Nakuru).
On 16 September 2018, 'heavily-armed' Ugandan police deployed to the disputed island of Migingo, prompting Kenyan fishermen to avoid sailing near the island.

14 September 2018: Several shops and homes were burned to the ground in the Musegekwa village, Njoro county, despite a police curfew in the town as a result of ethnic violence. Coordinates given for Nessuit village, which is nearby.

Arrests: During the week leading up to 8th September, Kenyan police reportedly arrested 163 Pakistani nationals in the city of Mombasa, as part of a nation-wide crackdown on illegal immigration. On September 5th, police also raided the offices of the China Global Television Network in Nairobi, arresting 13 Chinese civilians (including journalists).

Arrests: On August 28th, the Deputy Chief Justice of Kenya - Philomena Mwilu - was arrested on corruption and tax evasion charges, and released on bail. The move follows tensions between the presidency and the judiciary regarding the elections in 2017.

Arrests: On or before August 27th, counter-terror police arrested seven individuals suspected of being affiliated to Al Shabaab, in Ijara sub-county (Garissa county). Three of the suspects were later released.

Property destruction: on August 24th, and according to an Al Shabaab commander, the group destroyed power stations in Lamu town and Tana River town (for the latter, the location of Hola has been used). There has been no confirmation of this claim in other sources.

Property destruction: on August 24th, and according to an Al Shabaab commander, the group destroyed power stations in Lamu town and Tana River town (for the latter, the location of Hola has been used). There has been no confirmation of this claim in other sources.
Arrests: On 8 August, Evans Kidero, former Nairobi governor, was arrested alongside Lilian Wanjiru, Jimmy Mutuku and other influential businessmen and politicians.
Security measures: On 6 August, a new police border patrol unit with camels has been established to patrol remote sections of the Kenya-Somali border in Isiolo County.
On 2 August 2018, over 80 traders were arrested in the Lavington and Kawangware areas (Kilimani, Nairobi) in an operation against illegal structures. The demolitions are expected to continue.

Property destruction: 20 July. A former Member of County Assembly's house was set ablaze by unknown assailants. The arson attack occurred three days before the High Court was to deliver a ruling in an election petition between him and the current MCA Wilson Kuyo.

Movement of forces: In July, Al Shabaab forces were reported to have moved into Meru county from Somalia, according to a local official, who has also claimed Al Shabaab were planning attacks in the area.
Movement of forces: 02 July. 200 members of al Shabaab are spotted moving through Boni Forest in eastern Kenya, near the border with Somalia.
Looting: 24 May. Al Shabaab invaded Mandera, looted shops and lectured in a mosque for several hours before leaving.
Arrests: 20 May. An al Shabaab facilitor known as Francis Macharia Karishu is arrested in Nairobi.

Security measures: 08 May. The Kenyan police issued a terror alert urging Kenyans to remain extra vigilant ahead of Muslims' holy month of Ramadan that begins on May 15. Al Shabaab has historically operated in Mandera County.
Property destruction: 28 April. Residents accuse police of torching hundreds of houses in Kisiriri and Rumuruti. It is believed the police were pursuing a group of raiders.
Weapons seizure: 11 April. Police forces dismantle an al Shabaab camp in Ijara. No arrests reported, though a number of weapons were recovered.
Defusal: 21 March. An explosive is found in the Kaptembwa area of Nakuru. Police forces safely disposed of the device. The perpetrators are not known.

On 3 July 2018, a bomb disposal squad from the Kenya Defence Forces succesfully defused an IED (the source attributes Al Shabaab as being responsible for placing the device) in between Sangailu and Hangaro (Sangailu coded as the location, with coordinates for the precise site accurate to 5km taken from the source).
On 7 March 2018, police arrested a former member of parliament in Rumuruti (Laikipia West, Laikipia) for allegedly inciting local communities to turn against each other.
Defusal: While on patrol between along the Hulugho-Galmagalla road, security forces spotted two al Shabaab IEDs and dismantled them.
Property destruction: 'Land grabbers' attack a farm in Chepchoina, destroy 200 houses. The attack displaced a number of people.

Non-violent activity: The dawn attack at the residence of former Vice President Kalonzo Musyoka in Karen has been termed as an attempt to intimidate the Opposition over their strong position on electoral reforms. No injuries reported.

Property destruction: Al-Shabab militants have destroyed a Hormuud communication mast located on the Somalia border town of Elwak. Police say the militants were retaliating to earlier reports of locals communicating with Somalia security forces and the Kenya Amisom troops.

In Ishakani Village in Lamu East, more than 100 heavily armed insurgents took over the area and preached radical teachings to the residents. They hoisted their flag at a deserted local police station before going back to their hideouts. Sources revealed that the attackers have also been conducting daily prayers at mosques in the area at will.

Detonation: An explosive thrown from a moving car hit the perimeter wall of a church, causing a security scare in Mandera Town. The device, according to an eyewitness, exploded immediately after the speeding Toyota Probox turned at a corner.

Property destruction: A church at the centre of a land tussle was destroyed on 15 November at Jogoo area in Kisii Town. Church officials said hired goons descended on Millennium SDA Church and vandalised it.

Movement of forces: on 29 October, armed men from Waithaka and Ndonyo area raided Kabiria. Young men were armed with pangas and threatened to conduct a door-to-door search to flush out Luos and Luhyas, who they said were living on their land. No actual violence reported.
Non-violent activity: Villagers from the Luo and Kalenjin communities armed themselves against each other on 28 October in Kisumu County.

Non-violent activity: In Chakol estate in Busia, police threw teargas cannisters into houses to flush out the inhabitants. They claimed to be searching for the youth who had disrupted the voting the previous day. No reported injuries.

assoc_actor_1: IEBC: Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (Kenya)
notes: Non-violent activity: The IEBC announces that the voting for the presidential elections in Homa Bay, Kisumu, Migori, Siaya will be postponed to the 28th. The re-run was later cancelled with a new date to be announced.
Movement of forces: The government decides to deploy 130,000 police officers to the locations of Homa Bay Migori, Siaya, Kisumu and Migori to protect voters.

Non-violent activity: Police raid the house of former Kakamega Senator Boni Khalwale in search for materials that can be used to disrupt the Thursday election. The police claims that Mr. Khalwale was storing tyres to provide to mobilised youth, which would use them to light pyres.

Movement of forces: The government's military operation in Boni Forest meant to flash out suspected al-Shabab militants is set to be extended for an unspecified period in Lamu, Garissa and Tana River counties.
Destruction of property: Shops at Gorofani are set alight. Perpatrators not known.

Officers conducting the ongoing multi-agency security Operation in Lamu have discovered and destroyed three key Al-Shabaab hideouts at Lango la Simba in Witu Division of Lamu West. The raids took place on or before 10/09.

Property destruction: Al-Shabab fighters attacked the Kenyan village of Gamba in Tana River County [in the country's coastal region], targeting government installations in the area. The extent of the damage or whether anyone was killed or injured in the attack is not year clear. Phone networks in the area broke down after the raid.
Al Shabaab militants destroyed an electricity pylon near Gamba, causing a blackout across Lamu county.
Movement of forces: Nasa tallying centre in Westlands, Nairobi,was raided at night by hooded gunmen - suspected to be police agents - on 4 August.
Property destruction: Houses were burned in villages on the Isiolo-Meru border as part of an ongoing border conflict between the counties.
Movement of forces: On 5 July, the government deployed troops to Lamu to look for al-Shabab who have been attacking civilians and police officers in the county.
Property destruction: suspected ODM supporters vandalised and damaged the campaign truck of the Jubilee candidate, Hassan Omar.

Arrests: Police have arrested 27 armed youth said to have been planning to disrupt a political rally in Rabuor, Kisumu County. Several crude weapons, including three machetes and two knives, and two rolls of bhang were found.
The Kenyan security forces rescued 2 of the 4 pupils kidnapped during the Al Shabaab attack on Kiunga two days previously. No reports of clashes.
Police arrested 27 youths armed with crude weapons, who were planning to disrupt a NASA rally in Nyando.
Arrests: Police have arrested more than 80 people suspected to be 'terrorists' in Eastleigh.
Detonation: The IED planted by Al Shabaab, and targeting Kenya Defence Forces (KDF) along the Milimani-Baure's supply route detonated without any casualties or injuries on the side of KDF.
Property destruction: Over 100 camels have been killed and at least 47 houses torched by bandits who locals believe are security officers on the border of Kitui and Tana River counties.
Property destruction: Al Shabaab militants destroyed a communications mast in Wajir
Unidentified people wielding machetes destroyed a candidate's billboard.

Looting: Cattle rustlers attacked the village of Chemorongion in April or early May 2017 (the source does not incidate an exact date). The source does not indicate any fatalities or injuries. 300 livestock were stolen.
Property destruction: A group of youths attacked a vehicle carrying ODM ballot materials in Mosando, Bogiakumu. The driver said he was blocked by individuals on motorbikes.
Non-violent activity: Mr Kenneth Kinyanjui, who is fighting for the Ikinu MCA's seat, went missing on Tuesday night before resurfacing on Tuesday
Non-violent activity: On Friday, the Kabete Jubilee parliamentary aspirant Charles Chege disappeared and resurfaced on Sunday morning
Non-violent activity: 10 April, 23:00EAT, Mandera, Kenya: al Shabaab militants entered Mandera and hijacked two pick-up trucks.
Unidentified arsonists petrol-bombed the Migori ODM offices ahead of a party rally the following day.
Movement of forces: Suspected Al-Shabaab hijacked a Kenyan government vehicle in the border town of Elwak in Mandera country. The attackers released the driver and reportedly drove into Somalia.

Property destruction: Suspected 'cattle herders' burn down a tourist lodge on the Laikipia Plateau. The herders may have torched the lodge in retaliation to an ongoing security operation in the area. The hotel was empty at the time of the attack.
Kenya's president deployed the military to quell violence related to drought.
Property destruction: A UK national's home that had been burnt down by Pokot or Samburu raiders on 03/03.

Security Measures: More than 30 schools have been closed due to persistent attacks by armed Pokot militia in Baringo county. Closed schools include Ngaratuko, Chemoe, Yatya, Tuluk, Kagir, Loruk, Chepkesin, Kapturo, Toboroi, Barsuswo and Lokorotabim in Baringo North.
Non-violent activity: Heavily armed Somali militia/herders are reported to have encorached onto farms in Kitui, armed with AK-47s and displaced unprotected farmer settlements.

Non-violent activity: Pokot bandits have resorted to blocking roads using twigs and stones. Currently, they have barricaded Makutani-Arabal road, Norokwei-Kiserian road and speculation is high that they are likely to close the Arabal-Sirata road in a bid to block security officers from flushing them out of their hideouts.
Non-violent activity: on 25 December, a group of suspected Pokot militia raided a village near Arabel and forced locals who were attending a church service to flee. No one was injured.
Property destruction: Offices of the Vihiga County government are destroyed by unidentified arsonists.

Property destruction: on 20 November, a group of unknown people armed with machetes and rungus attempted to break into the house of the Mvita MP in Majengo Sega area of Mvita. They pelted the house with stones and smashed a car. No injuries reported.
Movement of forces: Al Shabaab enters two villages in Ijara sub-county, forcing residents to hear a lecture in their local mosque.

Defusal: Military forces foil an ambush on a convoy in Lamu by identifying IEDs and detonating them. No injuries. The security forces are reportedly in pursuit of the suspected attackers in the area. The planned attack and subsequent security sweep took place on 12/07.

Movement of forces: Forty-five members of al Shabaab are witnessed crossing into Kenya at Sugrow, Wajir County. One group of 13 was sighted headed towards Gerille, another towards Konton and another towards Gumarey areas of Wajir East.
Property destruction: A gang on the night of 31/01 raided Meru Governor Peter Munyas home and vandalised one of his official security cars. The governor was away, and was not harmed.
A threat is announced and a bomb later discovered in a Catholic church in Kutu. Its discovery caused congregants to panic and flee. Police later detonated the explosive without injury.
Al Shabaab overtakes Bula Golol in Garissa Country without resistance, then begins preaching to the residents. Military forces had fled the area prior to the al Shabaab arrival.
Al Shabaab forces briefly take over Basuba in Lamu Country. Once there, al Shabaab leaders addressed the town and met with elders before retreating.
Reports indicate that Al Shabaab overtook Milimani village in Lamu on the night of 18/07. No violence was reported.

Non-violent activity: Al Shabaab reportedly erects a series of road blocks between Garba Tula and Modogashe townships [north-eastern Kenya] for purposes of extorting money from motorists. Despite these assertions, the local government denies these claims. Exact date unknown.
Al Shabaab creates a heavy presence in Lafey village effectively 'taking over' the village. The presence of al Shabaab caused several villagers to flee for safety.
Al Shabaab 'catches two military posts (in Sangailu and Hulugho) by surprise,' no violence reported.
Al Shabaab 'catches two military posts (in Sangailu and Hulugho) by surprise,' no violence reported.
Ethiopian soldiers armed with AK-47 rifles cross into Kenya aboard 10 vehicles and reportedly take over a police station in North Horr.
Non-violent activity: Ten armed members of al Shabaab hijack a bus carrying ten passengers, deboard them and take the bus across the border into Somalia. No violence reported.
Defusal: Police uncover and remove an IED in Mandera County, near the Somali border on 12/04.
Non-violent activity: Suspected al Shabaab attack a Lamu bound bus in Nyangoro. Four shots were reported fired, though no one was reported injured.
Defusal: Two IEDs are discovered by police in Nairobi (Mlango Kubwa and Pangani areas). One or both were destroyed with a controlled explosion.

Defusal: An explosive device is discovered in Kenyatta Barracks along the Gilgil-Nyahururu road. The device was discovered before it could be detonated. Perpetrators not known. Date not provided - source dated 08/12.
Non-violent activity: A group of Muslim youth forcibly overtake a mosque in Mombasa, and ejected its moderate imam and management committee. Injuries/causalities not known.
Arrests: Police forces launch a major security sweep in the wake of an attack in Mombasa. 300 suspects arrested.
Defusal: Police discover and dismantle an explosive planted at the Boys Town Primary School in Garissa. Police believe the target of the explosives was the school children. Perpetrator unknown.

Arrests: A force of 6,100 police and soldiers are deployed to the heavily Somali populated Eastleigh neighbourhood to 'flush out illegal immigrants and suspected al Shabab members.' 3,000 arrests reported (Associated Press).
A man is dead after the explosive device he was assembling detonated during construction. Police suspect 'sympathizers of Somali Islamic extremists.'
Arrests: Police in Eastleigh arrest over 100 Somali expatriates with suspected connections to al Shabaab in a night time operation.
Defusal: Two bombs are discovered near soldiers of faith church in Huruma, Nairobi and were disabled before detonation. It is not clear if the soldiers were the intended target.
Kenyan police intercept Al Shabaab truck carrying explosives in northeastern Kenya
Property destruction: Unidentified armed group attacks two communication masts in refugee camp; no civilians were injured in the attack, though equipment and walls were destroyed
Bombs found placed near IDP houses; police detonate and remove bombs
Unexploded bomb discovered inside bus in Nairobi
Bomb found placed in matatu
MRC members throw petrol bombs at counting centre; the bombs failed to explode
Property destruction: Chiefs office set ablaze by unknown armed group
Non-violent activity: Armed men surround polling center, forcing officials to change to a new voting location
Movement of forces: MRC members spotted taking oaths and preparing attacks during the elections
Property destruction: Toposa ethnic militia burns pastureland in Kenya
Three suspected bombers killed when the bomb they were planting blew up. The police suspect a link with Al Shabaab
Movement of forces: Turkana raiders take up arms and gather for revenge attacks against Pokot ethnic group. Police kept vigil to prevent attacks from taking place
Two suspected Al Shabaab bombers died when explosives they were carrying went off
Defusal: Police encounter and IED and are able to detonate the bomb without incident
Recruitment: MRC stages secret oath-taking sessions to recruit youth
Movement of forces: Turkana raiders involved in attack against police forces said to be moving towards Nachola using women and children as human shields
Non-violent activity: Al Shabaab assembles IEDs in Majengo
Defusal: Police find grenade on bus bound for Kaloleni
Recruitment: MRC recruiting youths and holding 'oathing' ceremonies to add to their numbers

Recruitment: Police raid militants oath-taking ceremony. Police reported a rise in oath-taking ceremonies used by militant groups linked to MRC to recruit youth to join their cause. The ceremonies involve military training and initiation practices
Recruitment: Police report rise in oath-taking ceremonies used by militant groups linked to MRC to recruit youth to join their cause. The ceremonies involve military training and initiation practices
Property destruction: Arsonists burn Garissa police station
Police seize explosives from suspected Al Shabaab members
Non-violent activity: HRW report states Kikuyu ethnic group has been arming themselves in preparation for election season in March of 2013
Non-violent activity: HRW report states Kalenjin ethnic group has been arming themselves in preparation for election season in March of 2013
Non-violent activity: HRW report states Kalenjin ethnic group has been arming themselves in preparation for election season in March of 2013
Non-violent activity: HRW report states Kikuyu ethnic group has been arming themselves in preparation for election season in March of 2013
Two Al Shabaab suspects arrested with explosive devices in Kitale town

actor1: Al Hijra Muslim Youth Centre Militia
notes: Recruitment: Al Hijra (formerly known as Muslim Youth Council) is actively recruiting youth to fight in Somalia and Eritrea
Defusal: Bomb discovered in Ongata Rongai
Defusal: Police seize explosive materials from suspects in Nairobi slum
Weapons Seizure: Suspected Al Shabaab sympathizers hijack public service vehicle near Somali border
Arrests: Kenyan police arrest two Iranians for suspected links with militant organizations. The men were allegedly planning a terror attack in either Nairobi or Mombassa
Recruitment: MRC said to be recruiting children in secession drive
Property destruction: Youth active in MRC caught vandalizing church with MRC slogans
Movement of forces: Concerns that Somali Al Shabaab fighters escaping to Kenya and hiding among the civilian population
Bomb found near home of former president Kenyatta

Recruitment: Police Forces of Kenya (2002-) will recruit additional 3, 500 police officers as the country seeks to counter growing insecurity within its borders perpetuated by the Somali-based group Al Shabaab and emerging national threats ahead of its general election in March 2013.

Non-violent activity: Government of Kenya (2002-) convicts Paul Kipkemboi Ruto to life for murder during during Kenyas 2007-08 postelection violence-constitutes first conviction for actions during this postelection violence.
Police close a bridge when a package is discovered to be a suspected bomb.
Recruitment: MRC said to be actively recruiting in Mombasa
Recruitment: Al Shabaab said to be recruiting Kenyans from slums of Nairobi

Kenyan police said they had seized explosive equipment in a refugee camp near the Somali border, calling it a major breakthrough in their investigation into attacks blamed on rebels linked to al Qaeda.

On 31 March 2022, suspected Somali ethnic militia shot and killed three charcoal dealers (believed to be of Meru ethnic) at Kiambogo area in Tigania east (Tigania West, Meru). The attack is believed to have been a retaliation for an earlier incident where a Meru militia is alleged to have shot and killed a 15-year-old herder from the Somali ethnic group on 30 March (coded separately).

On 30 March 2022, suspected Pokot pastoral militia shot and killed three men, while three others sustained gunshot injuries, in Tandar village within Muchongoi ward (event coded to Mochongoi (Mogotio, Baringo).

On 30 March 2022, suspected Meru ethnic militia shot and killed a 15 year old herder (believed to be of Somali) for allegedly crossing the border at Kiambogo area in Tigania east (Tigania West, Meru).

Around 30 March 2022 (week of), suspected Merrile militia shot and killed five Turkana peace actors in the Todonyang and Kibish border villages, coded as Kibish (Kibish, Turkana). The motive for the attack is unknown.

On 29 March 2022, unidentified militia abducted a blogger (journalist) affiliated to a United Democratic Alliance (UDA) gubernatorial aspirant, from a street in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu). The blogger was later released on 30 March 2022.

On 26 March 2022, unidentified communal militia shot and killed a Naroosura group ranch official, while injuring another at Quarantine area near Nkoben (Narok South, Narok). The motive of the attack is allegedly linked to the unfairness in the subdivision of the ranch.
On 25 March 2022, suspected Samburu pastoral militia shot and killed one person while two others sustained gunshot wounds at Kom Durte (Merti, Isiolo).

assoc_actor_1: Azimio La Umoja Coalition; ODM: Orange Democratic Movement
notes: On 24 March 2022, presumed Orange Democratic Movement (ODM) party private security, assaulted and injured a standard journalist and a star journalist at an Azimio meeting, at Chungwa House in Lavington (Dagoretti North, Nairobi). A phone belonging to one of the journalists had its screen smashed. It is alleged that the journalists had written stories the party disapproved of. The party later issued an apology.

source: Kenya Broadcasting Corporation; Citizen (Kenya); Capital FM; Star (Kenya)
notes: On 22 March 2022, suspected Gabra militia attacked a vehicle, between Bubisa and Turbi, along the Marsabit-Moyale highway, near Galgallo (North Horr, Marsabit). At least 2 people (presumed from the Borana ethnic group) were killed and four others critically injured.

source: Kenya Broadcasting Corporation; Kenya Standard; Daily Nation (Kenya); Opera News (Kenya)
notes: On 20 March 2022, suspected Pokot pastoral militia, dressed in police attire, attacked Koitialal village near Tunyo (Marakwet West, Elgeyo Marakwet). Two people were killed including a pastor, and seven others injured. Over 100 animals were stolen, and unknown amount of property destroyed.
Around 20 March 2022 (as reported), suspected Pokot militia attacked the Kapyego ward (Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet), resulting in two men injured.

On 20 March 2022, unidentified clan militia (referred to as land cartels/militia and/or criminal gangs) attacked and killed a man in Bula Mzuri neighborhood of Garissa town (Garissa, Garissa), allegedly over a land dispute. They also touched his house. A number of people sustained injuries during the incident.

On 19 March 2022, suspected Samburu pastoral militia attacked Aregae neighborhood near Ngeramara town (Isiolo, Isiolo). The militia raped a 50-year-old woman (believed to be Turkana in ethnicity), before making away with more than 500 goats and 11 cows.

On 19 March 2022, suspected Pokot militia attacked Koitialal village near Tunyo (Marakwet West, Elgeyo Marakwet). There were no causalities. Unknown number of animals were stolen. Hundreds of residents of Koitialal village were displaced into the hilly Elgeyo escarpment, following attacks from suspected Pokot militia.

On 19 March 2022, unidentified clan militia (referred to as land cartels/militia and/or criminal gangs) attacked and killed a man in Burburis neighbourhood of Garissa town (Garissa, Garissa), allegedly over a land dispute. No further information.

On 17 March 2022, suspected Pokot militia attacked a taxi vehicle, plying the Lodwar-Kitale road, near Kainuk (Lobokat, Turkana). The driver and one passenger, a Spanish national, sustained bullet wounds.

On 17 March 2022, six suspected police officers (in-plain clothes) abducted an Al- Shabaab ex-convict at Shanzu (Kilifi South, Kilifi), moments after being released from the Shimo la Tewa prison. The ex-convict resurfaced on 3 September 2022.
On 13 March 2022, 5 unidentified men abducted a boda boda taxi operator in Dungiri village near Kabazi (Subukia, Nakuru). He is yet to be found.

On 11 March 2022, suspected al-Shabaab militants attacked the site of a Chinese Construction Company in Bodhei (Lamu West, Lamu county). The militants set a blaze a construction vehicle (tipper) and several motorcycles belonging to casual labourers. Al Shabaab claimed killing 4 people.

On 10 March 2022, unidentified militia attacked citizens at a public rally organized by a United Democratic Alliance (UDA) governorship aspirant in Mbalambala (Bura, Tana River). Dozens were injured during the incident.

On 9 March 2022, more than 10 suspected Pokot pastoralist militia attacked Ngaratuko village (Baringo North, Baringo), and made away with unknown number of livestock beloging to 3 families. There were no fatalities.

On 9 March 2022, suspected Pokot pastoral militia attacked Kombases village (Marakwet West, Elgeyo Marakwet). The militia injured one man from the Marakwet pastoral ethnic group, before making away with an unknown number of livestock.
On 7 March 2022, suspected pokot militia attacked the Kapkosum area of Mochongoi (Baringo). Casualties unknown.
On 5 March 2022, suspected Pokot militia attacked Duka Moja village, near Mochongoi (Kisanana, Baringo). One person was killed while two others sustained gunshot injuries during the incident.
On 4 March 2022, suspected Pokot ethnic militia shot and killed 4 civilian pastoralist and stole unknown number of livestock in Kasiela (Marigat, Baringo county). No further information.

On 4 March 2022, suspected Pokot pastoral militia ambushed and killed a milk vendor and his pillion passenger (both riding a vehicle), at Duka Moja village, near Mochongoi (Mogotio, Baringo). The motive of the attack is unknown.
On 3 March 2022, suspected Borana ethnic militia shot and killed one ethnic Degodia lorry driver near Archers Post (Samburu East, Samburu county). The motive was due to retaliatory attack.
Around 2 March 2022 (as reported), suspected Pokot militia attacked Sinoni area (Marigat, Baringo county). One person, a 16-year-old, form 3 student was killed and unknown number of animals stolen.
On 2 March 2022, suspected Borana ethnic militia shot and killed two ethnic Degodia pastoralists in the Attan area of Ngeramara (Isiolo). The motive was due to retaliatory attack

On 28 February 2022, suspected Degodia pastoral militia ambushed and killed two men from the Borana ethnic group at Lakole village in Merti (Merti, Isiolo county). The motive of the attack remains unknown.
On 28 February 2022, suspected Al Shabaab millitant shot and killed an assistant chief on his way home, at Hargasu area, 8KM from Mandera town (Mandera East, Mandera County).

On 24 February 2022, a female MCA member accused two men known to her (presumed UDA members) for indecently assaulting and shoving her during a UDA rally at the Mutito alias Mutitu (Kitui East, Kitui county). Police are investigating the claims. [women targeted: politicians]
Around 23 February 2022 (as reported), suspected Pokot militia opened fire on herders, killing 3, near Kabetwa (Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet). 2 herders sustained gunshot wounds.
On 21 February 2022, unidentified militia, riding on a motorbike, shot and killed a police officer [assumed off duty] in Marsabit town (Saku, Marsabit county). The motive of the attack is unknown

Around 21 February 2022 (between 19 February - 24 February), armed men who identified themselves as police officers abducted a UDA party grassroots' mobiliser in Kawangware (Kabiro, Nairobi). His body was later found in the Nyeri river. Location coded as Kawangware (Nairobi).
On 20 February 2022, unidentified militia, attacked and killed a community elder within Marsabit (Saku, Marsabit county). The motive of the attack is unknown.

On 19 February 2022, suspected armed Pokot militia shot and killed a teacher on his way home from a Sunday service at Kipyebo Catholic church near Tunyo (Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet county) where he also served as a catechist.
